content.description:
This has steep face climbing on some crystal knobs past four bolts. A fixed pin protects the final move onto the slab. The finishing slab doesn’t have any fixed gear and is runout, but it’s super mellow.

If you've climbed in Tuolumne, the crystal knobs on this climb may be vaguely reminiscent of that experience, hence the name "Tuo."
content.protection:
4 bolts and 1 fixed pin (no longer) plus a 2 bolt anchor.

Per

angus Morrison

: the fixed pin on this route is now missing. It came out with a tap with a carabiner.
content.location: This is the lefthand of the two bolted routes and climbs the center of the gray face.

content.description: Something New has steep face climbing that starts on a dirty, wide crack that angles up and right across the face. The finishing slab doesn’t have any fixed gear and is runout, but it’s super mellow.
content.location: This is the righthand of the two bolted routes on the face.

climbs.name: Hideout Crack
climbs.fa: unknown, surely climbed by someone long before, at least by 1995

content.description: This is a cool little crack, too bad it wasn't twice as tall! Climb this crack in a variety of ways as it angles right up the wall, topping out on the slab above.
content.protection: A small rack to #2 Camalot and two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This ascends the crack to the left of

Tuo Much Fun

.

climbs.name: Hideout Corner
climbs.fa: unknown, surely climbed by someone long before

content.description: Climb the corner that becomes steeper at the top. It can be tricky to protect.
content.protection: A small rack to #2 Camalot and a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: This ascends the corner on the left side of the wall.
